Award.AwardTitle: Fertility Transition and Emerging Differences in Parental Investment and Children's Economic Roles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Harvard University anthropologist Dr. Karen L. Kramer will undertake research on how economic transitions affect fertility patterns and children's lives. Subsistence farmers worldwide are experiencing changes in their traditional agrarian systems, becoming less self-sufficient and more dependent on selling their labor. These changes have significant demographic effects: in many populations, fertility rates decline dramatically. However, little is known about how this happens, how much variaibility there might be between households when not all of them prosper in the new economy, and how this affects the health and life quality of children whose labor often underwrote the old economic systems. Kramer's research is designed to answer these questions.

The research will be carried out in the rural Maya village of Xculoc, Campeche, Mexico. The research design takes advantage of the fact that detailed data on labor, economy, health, and demographics were collected in this village in the 1990s. Since that time, the village has begun the process of transitioning from a subsistence agricultural economy to one that is increasingly dependent on wage labor, cash, and the market economy. These extant data will serve as the baseline against which to measure change, determine increases in household variability, and explore the possible causes. The researcher will collect economic, demographic, growth, time allocation and energy expenditure data for 80 households and 390 children under the age of 20.

The project's primary research questions are:
1) What impact does subsistence change have on child quality (growth performance, diet, education, medical intervention and labor)?
2) What is the relationship between household economic characteristics and fertility outcomes?
3) What is the relationship between fertility trends and children's labor contributions?
4) Do parents with few resources or opportunities to improve their children's futures, maintain or even increase family size? While other parents have fewer children and invest more in their health and education?

This research will help social scientists and policy makers to understand why high fertility persists in traditional communities and its relation to economic transitions. Small-scale anthropological studies and individual data offer valuable insight into these demographic processes, which are otherwise masked by national and regional trends. Findings from this resarch will be of interest to organizations interested in understanding the family planning and changing health and economic needs of communities experiencing economic transitions. Funding this research also supports the training of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How does economic development affect children’s health, development and learning? In our own society the answer is difficult to assess because numerous social factors --such as socioeconomic status, parents’ education, marital status, or level of community inequality -- confound identifying a straightforward relationship.  However, research in small-scale societies where education, health care, birth control, market foods, wage labor and a cash economy are being introduced for the first time can provide a clearer understanding of the effects that global trends in economic development have on children.  Anthropologist Dr. Karen L Kramer and her team (Harvard University; University of Utah) investigated the idea that under changing economic conditions, child outcomes will become more individually variable, and inequality will begin to emerge as parents anticipate different futures for their children. To test this idea, data were collected in a remote Yucatec Maya community in Mexico.  This was a unique opportunity to develop understanding of the effects of economic development on children because we have been working with the Maya for over 20 years and have long-term economic and demographic data that span the recent introduction of new life style and family planning options.  This allows us to control for both community-level and individual-level traits that have changed over the past 20 years. Our project has shown that across all measures of fertility, wealth status and child quality (level of education, growth outcomes and survival), differences among children have become much more pronounced, and education, wealth and health disparities are emerging for the first time.  While economic development often is assumed to have positive effects (reduced fertility and higher per capita investments in children), it can also have unanticipated local effects. For example, we found that the children of mothers who recently became wage laborers are significantly smaller and in poorer health.  In another example, the prevalence of cesarean birth has greatly increased in recent years and is associated with a shift to bottle-feeding, greater morbidity and obesity during early childhood.  Anthropological studies in small-scale societies undergoing dramatic changes for the first time offer greater controls of genetic diversity, economic practices and lifestyle variation compared to most studies in developed countries where less homogeneous biology and behavior can make the identification of causal factors and outcomes more problematic. Generalizability of our study to the numerous small-scale societies worldwide currently engaged in these transitions is enhanced by the use of comparable quantitative methods. Besides increasing our quantified and scientific understanding of the relationship between economic development and child outcomes, findings from this research have important implications to developing cost-effective policy and community outreach programs that have desired health and quality of life outcomes.  

The broader impacts of this study to the public have included: 1) providing scientific and STEM-field research experience to undergraduate and graduate students; 2) developing a program of community outreach, training and participation among indigenous Maya in Yucatan, Mexico; 3) fostering academic and nonacademic relationships across the U.S.–Mexico border; 4) disseminating study results to Maya community members, and local school and health clinics; 5) presenting project findings to regional leaders and non-academic audiences in Mexico; 6) making anonymized data publicly accessible to scholars and institutions conducting cross-cultural research; 7) reporting our findings in high impact academic journals and public conferences.
